DOCNAME: CASE OF SEGHETI v. THE REPUBLIC OF MOLDOVA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Article 3 - Degrading treatment;Inhuman treatment) (Substantive aspect);Violation of Article 13 - Right to an effective remedy (Article 13 - Effective remedy)
JUDGES: Alvina Gyulumyan;Ján Šikuta;Johannes Silvis;Josep Casadevall;Kristina Pardalos;Luis López Guerra
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in Cricova .

CARDINAL . The applicant worked as a consultant for ORG in GPE . On DATE he was arrested by NORP police in GPE , GPE , on suspicion of having made false accusations against a third person . While the parties did not submit any copies of judgments concerning the applicant ’s criminal proceedings , it follows from his correspondence that on an unknown date he was convicted to DATE imprisonment . He was placed in detention in prison no . CARDINAL in PERSON ( previously known as prison no . CARDINAL ) on DATE . On DATE he was transferred to prison no . CARDINAL in Cricova . On DATE he was transferred to the GPE prison hospital ( prison no . CARDINAL ) , where he received inpatient treatment until DATE for hypertension and cardiac insufficiency .

CARDINAL . The applicant described the conditions of his detention in prison no . CARDINAL in PERSON as follows . He was detained with CARDINAL other people in a QUANTITY . m cell without ventilation or heating . Prisoners sometimes had to take turns to sleep and had to wait for a daily time - slot of TIME to obtain running tap water , which made hygiene issues in the prison a lot worse . The toilet was located in the cell itself and gave off a foul odour because there were no products to clean it with . The food was inedible .

CARDINAL . He described the conditions of his detention in prison no . CARDINAL as follows . On DATE he was placed in a cell measuring QUANTITY . m with CARDINAL other people , which left very little space for each detainee . In the absence of any work or other activities , he had nothing to do and spent most of his time in the cell .

CARDINAL . No bedding was given to the applicant and he had to ask his relatives to bring him some . The same was true of items of personal hygiene . He had to wear the same clothes he had been wearing when he was admitted to the prison , since no clothes were provided by the prison administration .

CARDINAL . Water from a single tap was available during DATE but not at TIME , and owing to the number of detainees in the cell it was not always possible to have access to it . Food was scarce and of very poor quality . The library contents were old and there were no reading materials about the Convention . The applicant also claimed that he had been given insufficient medical treatment in both detention facilities .

CARDINAL . According to the Government , the space available to the applicant in various cells of prisons no . CARDINAL and DATE always exceeded CARDINAL sq.m . In particular , in prison no . CARDINAL he was held in a detention block for working prisoners . The first cell he was detained in measured CARDINAL sq.m and accommodated CARDINAL people . Shortly thereafter he was transferred to a cell measuring CARDINAL sq.m , which accommodated CARDINAL detainees . He was later moved to another cell measuring DATE , which also accommodated CARDINAL detainees . All the cells had the correct number beds for detainees and were equipped with a water tap and a toilet .

CARDINAL . The Government submitted a list confirming that the applicant was given medical assistance on a number of occasions in both prisons no . CARDINAL and no . CARDINAL , including inpatient treatment for an ulcer in DATE .

CARDINAL . The relevant parts of the report by ORG for the Prevention of Torture and Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment ( the ORG ) concerning its visit to GPE from DATE read as follows ( unofficial translation ) :
“ DATE . The delegation visited CARDINAL establishments run by ORG : prison no . CARDINAL in PERSON [ and ] correctional facilities nos . CARDINAL and CARDINAL in Cricova ...

CARDINAL . In view of the economic situation in the country , the situation in the majority of prisons visited remained difficult and the delegation encountered a number of problems already identified during its visits in DATE and DATE in terms of the physical conditions of detention and regimes .

CARDINAL . Correctional facility no . CARDINAL has CARDINAL detention blocks where the prisoners were divided into different units , according to whether they were classed as workers ( units CARDINAL , CARDINAL , DATE and DATE ) or non - workers ( units CARDINAL , CARDINAL , DATE and CARDINAL) . Unlike correctional facility no . CARDINAL , despite the shabbiness of the LOC , the establishment gave an overall impression of cleanliness and satisfactory upkeep . The laudable efforts made in this regard deserve to be highlighted . But again , much depended on the resources [ available to the ] prisoners for fitting out and renovating the cells .

Physical conditions ranged from acceptable to good on occasion . This was the case as regards unit CARDINAL which held non - working detainees . Other dormitories DATE while remaining in an acceptable state of upkeep and cleanliness – presented difficult conditions there being , in some cases , fewer beds than occupants , windows with panes missing and a lack of basic amenities , certain essentials ( such as mattresses , sheets , blankets or crockery ) having been obtained through the charity of fellow - prisoners . Again , living space was often restricted in some of the dormitories , a situation which was partially alleviated by an open - door policy within the sections .

CARDINAL . Except in the Lipcani Re - education ORG , where the efforts made in this respect regard are to be highlighted ... the quantity and quality of ORG food everywhere is a source of grave concern . The delegation was inundated with complaints regarding the absence of meat and dairy products . The findings of the delegation , regarding both stock levels of food and the menus , confirm the credibility of these complaints . The delegation ’s findings also confirm that in certain places ( Colonies CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) the food served was repulsive and virtually inedible ( for instance , insects and vermin were present ) . This is hardly surprising , given the general state of the kitchens and their modest equipment .

The NORP authorities have always claimed financial difficulties in ensuring that prisoners receive adequate food . However , the ORG reiterates that this is a fundamental requirement of life that must be ensured by the ORG to persons in its care , and that nothing can exonerate it from such responsibility . Failure to meet this obligation is all the more unacceptable as , under legislation , working prisoners in the institutions visited contribute to the cost of feeding themselves and their fellow - prisoners . ...
CARDINAL . In the light of the above , the ORG recommends that the GPE authorities :
- ensure that each prisoner in correctional facility nos . CARDINAL and DATE has his own bed with the necessary bedding ( mattress , sheets , blankets ) and that all windows are glazed ;
- remove the screens from the windows in the cells in unit CARDINAL of correctional facility no . CARDINAL to allow for the proper entry of natural light and fresh air ;
- commence the refurbishment of the sanitary equipment in correctional facility nos . CARDINAL and CARDINAL and in the Re - education ORG forthwith , in the light of the remarks made above ;

- immediately guarantee that inmates in Prison nos . CARDINAL , ... CARDINAL and DATE , as well as in all other affected prisons , receive adequate food served in accordance with the basic rules of hygiene ;
- take all requisite measures to ensure adequate water , electricity and fuel supplies in correctional facility nos . CARDINAL and DATE , as well as in all other affected prisons ; ... ”

CARDINAL . The relevant parts of the report of the Special Rapporteur on torture and other cruel , inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment concerning his visit to GPE from DATE ( ORG , document DATE , CARDINAL DATE ) read as follows :
“ B. Conditions in places of detention
Institutions under ORG

CARDINAL . Undoubtedly , progress has been achieved in improving conditions of detention . However , some of the institutions visited by the Special Rapporteur were heavily overcrowded . The authorities themselves pointed out that Institution No . CARDINAL in PERSON was severely overcrowded - on DATE of the visit it held QUANTITY persons with the official capacity being CARDINAL ( see also appendix ) . The Special Rapporteur was informed of Government plans to close down this institution .

CARDINAL . Common problems at all pre- and post - trial prisons are the poor hygienic conditions , restricted access to health care and lack of medication as well as risk of contamination with tuberculosis and other diseases . Whereas the Special Rapporteur notes that the minimum norms regarding nutrition of detainees ( Government Decision n. CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE ) are checked on a DATE basis and that , according to the financial plan of ORG , the food budget for DATE had almost doubled in comparison to DATE and is set to rise further , he also received consistent allegations regarding the poor quality and quantity of food . ... ”
CARDINAL . In its report for DATE ( page CARDINAL – “ Conditions of detention ” ) , ORG ( “ FAC ” , which also acts as ORG ) found , inter alia , that :

“ Regarding personal hygiene , clothing and bedding , despite [ the fact that ] Government decision no . CARDINAL ( DATE ) concerning minimum DATE food requirements and the issuing of items of personal hygiene provides for the issuing of soap to detainees for bathing and other sanitary - hygienic needs , this has remained unfulfilled during DATE . ”
CARDINAL . In its report for DATE ( page CARDINAL et seq . – “ Conditions of detention ” ) ORG found , inter alia , that :

“ ... [ T]he ORG informed the ORG that meat and fish products are provided [ to detainees ] whenever possible . At the same time , that authority stated that , owing to the difficult financial situation , during DATE the detainees in prison no . CARDINAL in ORG received PERCENT of their normal quotas of meat and fish products respectively . In this connection , the Minister of ORG submitted information concerning the expenditure on ORG food in DATE . The cost amounted to MDL CARDINAL , whereas the budgetary need for DATE was , according to ORG draft budget , MDL CARDINAL . The DATE cost of feeding a detainee in DATE was MDL CARDINAL [ approximately ORG CARDINAL ] , while the DATE budgetary need was MDL CARDINAL . This statistic was often cited by prison administrations to justify why they were unable to provide detainees with meat and fish ... ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG adopted Decision no . CARDINAL approving ORG for DATE . ORG included a number of objectives to be achieved over a DATE period and was aimed at improving conditions of detention , including reducing overcrowding , improving medical treatment , introducing detainees to employment and encouraging their social reintegration , as well as carrying out training for personnel . Regular reports were to be submitted regarding the implementation of ORG . On DATE the Government adopted a decision on the principles of reorganisation of the prison system , together with the DATE - CARDINAL Action Plan for ORG , both having the aim , inter alia , of improving the conditions of detention in prisons .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date ORG produced a report entitled “ LAW by ORG Chapter CARDINAL of ORG for DATE , approved by ORG no . CARDINAL of DATE ” . On DATE ORG also produced a report on implementation of ORG . Both reports confirmed the insufficient funding of the prison system and the resulting failure to fully implement the Plan in GPE prisons , including prison no . CARDINAL in GPE . The first of these reports stated , inter alia , that “ as long as the aims and actions outlined in [ the National Human Rights Action Plan ] do not have the necessary financial support ... it will remain only a good intention of the ORG to protect human rights as described in ORG no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE ... ”
